awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Highly secure anticounterfeiting tags with deep learning software for reliable product authentication
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts and commercial potential of this I-Corps project enable a new platform for anticounterfeiting and authentication of physical goods. This project uses physically unclonable devices such as small anticounterfeiting tags that are essentially impossible to replicate. Because these tags are not readily copied by current manufacturing processes, they ensure uniqueness and security with distinct advantages over other chaosmetric approaches.  Current anticounterfeiting technologies often face challenges with low pattern complexity that allows the security tag to be copied, lack of facile authentication tools for high-complexity tags, and physical instabilities that can limit applications.  This technology platform addresses these challenges as it offers potential commercial applications in markets with high safety standards, such as pharmaceuticals and automobile parts, or in high-value sectors where authentication can often be destructive or difficult.

This I-Corps project develops two dimensional (2D) nanomaterials and their microstructures for use in anticounterfeiting applications.  By physically deforming the 2D nanomaterial thin films randomly, the resulting microstructure shows chaosmetric properties and high structural stability which can be utilized as a new type of anticounterfeiting tag.  The 2D nanomaterial tags may be irreplaceable and can be utilized in a variety of extreme environments such as at very high or very low temperatures, in strong acidic or basic solutions, and after physical washing.  These physical environments are areas where conventional anti-counterfeiting tags often fail.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The anticounterfeiting technology, MantaCode, was developed in Prof. Po-Yen Chen’s group at the University of Maryland (UMD), College Park. Our MantaCode technology is composed of three parts, (1) the physical security tags with unclonable and irreplicable features on environmentally stable 2D materials, (2) a deep learning-enabled software, enabling the users to read the tags through smartphone cameras for product authentication in a short period of time (<3 minutes), and (3) embedded DNA strands with pre-programmed sequences that can be extracted as a hidden security layer.

After attending the Summer 2021 cohort of NSF I-Corps program, our team has  discovered potential customers and examined the market hypotheses for our anticounterfeiting technology. From 104 interviews conducted in the NSF I-Corps, two market segments have been identified, where our anticounterfeiting technology can situate its value proposition in the manufacturing supply chain and the distribution channels of consumable packed goods.

Market research and value proposition. E-commerce consumables. Our anticounterfeiting technology can be a competitive brand protection tool for E-commerce consumables. The global e-commerce market size is valued at USD 9.09 trillion in 2019 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 14.7% from 2020 to 2027.  In the U.S. alone, counterfeit goods have cost U.S. merchants $41 billion dollars. During our interviews, two E-commerce companies, Dexas and FOREO, have expressed interests in investigating our anticounterfeiting technology onto their consumable products. For instance, Dexas manufactures cutting boards, kitchen tools, and specialty gadgets that stimulate culinary creativity at home and sells them on e-commerce places, such as Amazon. The general counsel and chief quality officer of Dexas, Mark Richmond, mentions to us that the company suffers close to a quarter of revenue loss from counterfeit products, and our technology is positioned to help the company protect the high-margin products and thus can prevent the revenue loss. On the other hand, FOREO encounters similar challenges in combating counterfeiting goods in their popular beauty product, Luna Mini 2, which get copied and replicated quickly especially in the Southeast Asia regions. The general counsel of FOREO, Evan Feldstein, thinks that our anticounterfeiting technology, due to its small tag size, can be applied onto lipsticks/small containers, which can prevent customers from buying illegitimate products and thus decrease counterfeit complaints from the customers by as much as 80% base on their previous experience. Aerospace component makers. The market of aerospace components is poised to grow by USD 3.68 billion during 2021–2025, progressing at a CAGR of over 6%. As our PUF patterns are based on GO that can sustain high heat as well as chemical washes, two aerospace component makers, PCC Structurals and Liatrisinc, are interested in using our tags for unit tracking and identification. As PCC Structurals mentions, the employers are being asked to track the given parts frequently (almost once a day), and the inventory lookup process can take hours to find the right documentation. PCC Structurals currently engraves serial numbers on parts which are very hard to track things, but many parts cannot even be engraved due to small sizes or curvy. Therefore, PCC Structurals is interested in using our technology as information-connection tags, which are small, flexible, resistant to heat, and readable by smartphones, which provide the value proposition to save time by at least 4 hours per day for each quality engineer. In sum, two market segments presented an opportunity for our technology to be sold to consumable packed goods with e-commerce channels, and/or aerospace component makers, where our technology provides clear value propositions to both markets.


Last Modified: 08/16/2022
Modified by: Po-Yen Chen
